raw_comment:
Our 6th grade math class noticed:
"There is one area in the Midwest that starts way later than other areas at the same latitude."
"The first week in Florida is still in winter"
"The latitude of the areas In March when the first leaf falls lines up with where Japan is." 

We are wondering: 
"What is your definition of 'first leaf'?" 
"How did you collect this data?"
"What time period did you get this average from?"
"What's going on with that area in the Midwest? Is there a difference in elevation causing the late first leaf?"
"Is this roughly the same in other countries with the same elevation?"

We think:
"Precipitation/climate probably effects the first leaf."
ace_sentences: A 6th grade math class noticed some patterns.
There is an area in the Midwest.
This area starts much later than other areas at the same latitude.
The first week in Florida is still in winter.
In March, the latitude of the areas where the first leaf falls aligns with the latitude of Japan.
The class wonders about the definition of the term first leaf.
The class asks how the data was collected.
The class asks from which time period the average was computed.
The class asks what happens in the area in the Midwest.
The class asks whether a difference in elevation causes the late first leaf in this area.
The class asks whether the pattern is roughly the same in other countries with the same elevation.
The class thinks that precipitation probably affects the first leaf.
The class thinks that climate probably affects the first leaf.
